body: Just an FYI here as well: I just observed an error caused by the exponential retry that breaks all task scheduling ( https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2196#issuecomment-290045055 ). I also updated the other PR to handle it properly.
Session is still opened in views? Also please verify your commit message against the guidelines pls (subject imperative and subject length)
Would love to see this in a patch or upcoming release since custom executors are broken atm.
fyi @jlowin https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2130 ended up including the separate `configparser` package, so this change should be okay to make now.
See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-1026 ... I think it's possible these changes broke the ability to specify certain config options via external command invocations.

A DAG that is `LatestOnlyOperator >> DummyOperator >> DummyOperator` should trigger it. [AIRFLOW-872](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-872) also has an example and does note that they ran into it with ShortCircuitOperator and BranchPythonOperator.

I don't have time to debug further right now, but I don't think that last change is working. The downstream tasks are no longer skipping and just run normally. Based on logging output I see, the query for task instances is not returning anything so nothing is getting marked as skipped.
Please update the commit message and squash

Ok. Indeed and that seems that there is an additional integrity issue with the DagRun. The issue remains a race condition with added issue that non existent tasks should be created. 

Thanks for the info 

@dhuang I verified with the Dag in AIRFLOW-872 that this change does work, I'll check why Postgres does not pass the tests (indeed it does not seems to have any task instances returned for some reason) and I'll make it a bit more defensive (checking for non existent tasks probably).

Also the issue with Postgres is most likely a DB deadlock, need to verify that and fix it.
@r39132, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @sekikn and @jlowin to be potential reviewers.
@andrewmchen, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @bolkedebruin and @jlowin to be potential reviewers.
